awd_titl_txt: SHF: SMALL: Deep Spiking Neural Networks: Algorithms, Architecture, and Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
This research attempts to explore new computing models by mimicking mammalian brains via new learning methods for brain-like Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs). However, the inherent mismatch between the characteristics of the CMOS devices and the functionality of neuron and synapses in the brain lead to drastic increase in circuit complexity. Spintronics based (non-CMOS) devices will be used in this research for hardware design of such brain-like architectures. The nanoHUB (www.nanohub.org) facility at Purdue University will be used to disseminate research results and to make the devices-to-systems simulation framework for neuromorphic computing available to researchers, educators, and students. The PI will develop new course modules to include the concept of using spin as a state variable for computation. These will be further used to update undergraduate and graduate level courses at Purdue, and made available through the nanoHUB.

Specifically, research on new spin-transfer torque devices will be exploited to investigate the possibility of mimicking functions of spiking neurons and synapses with efficient learning capabilities. The research will be driven by a combination of top-down and a bottom-up approach, where the team will explore algorithms that will be hardware compatible for implementing low-power on-chip learning mechanisms. The proposed research will develop new learning methods on brain-like spiking neural networks and use efficient device/circuit/algorithm co-design to achieve highly energy efficient spiking neural networks for image recognition and video analysis problems.

por.por_cntn:
When the project got started back in 2017, there was no good way of training spiking neural networks (SNNs). As a part of this research we developed efficient ways of training large scale deep SNNs. For fast and successful training, a conversion technique was used, where a trained standard deep neural network was used as a starting point. A neural threshold balancing technique assigned threshold to neurons suitable for leaky integrate and fire operations. A further improvement in training and the number of time steps required for computation included incremental training with spike based surrogate gradient backpropagation, and using leak as training parameter for the neurons. The results on image benchmarks show comparable accuracy to deep learning, few time-steps for inference, and almost 5X improvement in energy efficiency over standard ANNs. We also showed the SNNs with leaky integrate and fire neurons, mimic recurrent neural networks, and hence, more suitable for sequential tasks. Results of sentiment analyses, speech recognition, show that they required 2-8X less parameters than Long Short Term Memory Networks like LSTMs (a type of recurrent neural network), and achieved high efficiency with comparable accuracy. 

SNNs are also suitable for energy efficient edge applications. In particular, they can work seamlessly with dynamic vision sensors (an energy efficient camera that produces spike as inputs when there is a relative motion between the object and camera. Such spike based inputs are ideally suited for SNNs. For optical flow and depth estimation using DVS camera showed better accuracy compared to standard neural networks while achieving large energy efficiency.
